p: The climate of the UIB is complex and is the result of an intricate interaction between monsoon circulation, westerlies and the topography [ 46, 54â€“ 57]. The interaction between topography and precipitation manifests itself at various scales ranging from a synoptic scale of several hundreds of kilometers to an orographic meso-scale of less than 30 kilometers [ 58]. Along the Himalayan arc the monsoon influence is largest but this influence decreases in north-western direction where mid-latitude westerlies become increasingly important, e.g. at the junction of the Karakoram, Pamir and Hindu-Kush mountain ranges ( Fig 1). Precipitation from the westerlies is highest in winter when low-pressure systems reach the western margin of the greater Himalaya. This supply of moisture reaches higher elevations than the summer monsoon, which might be related to the higher tropospheric extent of the westerly airflow [ 55].
